You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 270, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 806, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 361, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 860, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 212, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 380, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 728, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
The masses, in kilograms, of small and large bags of wheat have the independent distributions N(16.0, 0.4) and N(51.0, 0.9) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the total mass of 3 randomly chosen small bags is greater than the mass of one randomly chosen large bag.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 131, 920, 151]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 71, 631, 89]]<|/det|>
A random variable \(X\) has probability density function f defined by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[368, 100, 623, 153]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}\frac{a}{x^2} - \frac{18}{x^3} & 2\leqslant x\leqslant 3,\\ 0 & \mathrm{otherwise}, \end{array} \right.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 163, 289, 181]]<|/det|>
where \(a\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 195, 146, 212]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 193, 301, 212]]<|/det|>
Show that \(a = \frac{27}{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 196, 920, 214]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 567, 181, 585]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 567, 390, 586]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\mathrm{E}(X) = \frac{27}{2}\ln \frac{3}{2} - 3.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 567, 920, 586]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
The lengths, in centimetres, of worms of a certain kind are normally distributed with mean \(\mu\) and standard deviation 2.3 . An article in a magazine states that the value of \(\mu\) is 12.7 . A scientist wishes to test whether this value is correct. He measures the lengths, \(x \text{cm}\), of a random sample of 50 worms of this kind and finds that \(\sum x = 597.1\) . He plans to carry out a test, at the \(1\%\) significance level, of whether the true value of \(\mu\) is different from 12.7 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 166, 146, 184]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 166, 744, 185]]<|/det|>
State, with a reason, whether he should use a one-tailed or a two-tailed test.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 166, 918, 185]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 291, 148, 308]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 291, 298, 308]]<|/det|>
Carry out the test.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 291, 920, 308]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The numbers of customers arriving at service desks \(A\) and \(B\) during a 10-minute period have the independent distributions \(\mathrm{Po}(1.8)\) and \(\mathrm{Po}(2.1)\) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 144, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 116, 920, 151]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that during a randomly chosen 15-minute period more than 2 customers will arrive at desk \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 133, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 917, 185]]<|/det|>

<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
An inspector waits at desk \(B\). She wants to wait long enough to be \(90\%\) certain of seeing at least one customer arrive at the desk.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
Find the minimum time for which she should wait, giving your answer correct to the nearest minute. [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
The number of accidents per year on a certain road has the distribution \(\mathrm{Po}(\lambda)\). In the past the value of \(\lambda\) was 3.3 . Recently, a new speed limit was imposed and the council wishes to test whether the value of \(\lambda\) has decreased. The council notes the total number, \(X\), of accidents during two randomly chosen years after the speed limit was introduced and it carries out a test at the \(5\%\) significance level.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 151, 144, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 151, 485, 168]]<|/det|>
Calculate the probability of a Type I error.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 151, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The council decides to carry out another similar test at the \(5\%\) significance level using the same hypotheses and two different randomly chosen years.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 771, 136]]<|/det|>
Given that the true value of \(\lambda\) is 0.6, calculate the probability of a Type II error.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 119, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 520, 186, 537]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 520, 920, 555]]<|/det|>
Using \(\lambda = 0.6\) and a suitable approximating distribution, find the probability that there will be more than 10 accidents in 30 years.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 537, 920, 555]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]
